title: DC Mayor: 'Kids will be required to come back to school in the fall'
body: Apparently, D.C. public school officials are making plans to have brick-and-mortar learning be universal, or nearly so, for city students starting in August."Kids will be required to come back to school in the fall," D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser said at a Monday press conference.Currently, only D.C. students whose families chose to have them return to in-person learning are physically present in school buildings. Other students continue to learn completely virtually.When asked if a virtual option would be made available for kids in the 2021/2022 school year, Bowser said: "If they have a need not to be in school, then that will be evaluated."Bowser promised more information soon, but added that District families "want to kind of turn the tide of learning loss" and "want their kids to be in safe school buildings with their teachers."Last week,  for their vaccine to include adolescents ages 12 through 15, but so far the youngest people eligible to be vaccinated in the U.S. are 16 years old. Pfizer is the only vaccine authorized for 16- and 17-year-olds. Moderna and Johnson & Johnson are still studying the impact of their shots on teens.Results are also expected soon from a U.S. study of Moderna’s vaccine in 12- to 17-year-olds. But in a sign that the findings were promising, the FDA already allowed both companies to begin U.S. studies in children 11 and younger, working their way to as young as 6-month-old.Children represent about 13% of COVID-19 cases documented in the U.S. And while children are far less likely than adults to get seriously ill, at least 268 have died from COVID-19 in the U.S. alone and more than 13,500 have been hospitalized, according to a tally by the American Academy of Pediatrics.
